definition:
A fibration is a map satisfying the homotopy lifting property. This is
easily seen to be equivalent to the following:

A map $f:X \to Y$ is a fibration if and only if there is a continuous
function which given a path, $\phi$, in $Y$ and a point, $x$, lying
above $\phi(0)$, returns a lift of $\phi$, starting at $x$.

Let $D^2$ denote the set of complex numbers with modulus less than or
equal to 1. An example of a fibration is the map $g: D^2 \to [-1,1]$
sending a complex number $z$ to $re(z)$.

Note that if we restrict $g$ to the boundary of $D^2$, we do not get a
fibration. Although we may still lift any path to begin at a prescribed
point, we cannot make this assignment continuously.

Another class of fibrations are found in fibre bundles.
